Benjamin Button.Action: Reflects with gratitude that his mother gave her life for him.
Shows gratitude and acknowledges the sacrifice of his mother for him.
Cries deeply as a newborn but does not show rejection or hostility towards others.
Baby cries in an unusual way, indicating an unusual condition that may challenge normal competence but shows uniqueness.
Crying persistently from birth despite unusual appearance.
Cries mournfully as a newborn, showing no control or agency in the situation.
Lies quietly in Queenie's bed, showing no agency or action in response to grim prognosis.
Smiles faintly in response to laughter despite being perceived as a dying old man.
Appears as a baby with a prematurely old appearance, showing a lonely smile despite physical condition.
Obeys Queenie's request to stop banging fork and uses napkin politely.
Annoys other old men by banging fork and moving wheelchair between them.
Reaches to hold Queenie's hand and shows affection toward her.
Wheels precariously toward edge of porch out of curiosity despite danger.
Expresses vulnerability and openness talking about feeling different and asking about how much longer he has to live.
Wheels himself precariously to the very edge of the porch to satisfy his curiosity despite potential danger.
Responds appropriately by rolling his wheelchair away from the edge to the safety of the old people when warned by Queenie.
Sits quietly alone listening to the house and people sleeping; feels safe and content in the presence of others
Curiously wheels himself to the window looking out at the world, trying to understand potential dangers
Wheels himself over to sit at the window looking outside, trying to see what's dangerous.
Sits alone in his wheelchair, listens to the sounds of the house and people sleeping, feels safe.
Listens respectfully and is awed by others' majesty and wisdom.
Accompanies Queenie to church tent, showing trust and companionship.
Passive, mostly silent observer of events rather than actively engaging.
Benjamin's mouth agape, awed, taken by him, his majesty.
Never thought about it (Tizzy's revelation about John Wilkes Booth).
Follows the Preacher's encouragement to stand up despite physical difficulty.
Follows the preacher's instruction and manages to stand despite great physical difficulty.
Falls after taking two unstable steps and initially cannot rise when commanded.
Hobbles across the stage with support, encouraged by others, showing perseverance and acceptance of help.
Looks around haplessly when The Preacher collapses, showing concern and vulnerability.
Stares unhappily at birthday cake and quietly leaves, avoiding birthday celebration with others.
Hobbles across the stage one crippled leg at a time, completing the walk with encouragement from others despite obvious difficulty.
Looks around haplessly after the Preacher collapses, showing confusion and lack of direction in a crisis.
Sits peacefully with elderly people on porch, observing life calmly and accepting the oddities of aging and death around him.
Enters kitchen quietly and notices visitors and conversations without interrupting, showing tolerance and patience.
Hesitates but eventually follows Ngunda Oti outside despite knowing the consequences.
Retreats quickly on his canes upon sensing Ngunda Oti's presence.
Retreats quickly on his canes when sensing someone approaching, showing awareness and caution.
Sits reading an oversized book of 'Imaginary Beings,' indicating intellectual curiosity.
Hesitates but eventually chooses to follow Mr. Oti outside despite knowing the consequences, showing some cautious decision-making followed by a willingness to take risks.
Refers to a condition 'madjembe' correctly when asked, showing a knowledge gap but also honest self-awareness.
Accepts help from Mr. Oti after spilling coca cola, shows openness and vulnerability.
Engages in conversation, shows interest and concern about Mr. Oti's situation.
Takes his first slug of a coca cola but drinks too much and spills it out of his nose, requiring assistance from Mr. Oti.
Although unsure if he can find his own way home, he nods affirmatively and moves along Bourbon Street, clasping his canes and determinedly walking despite physical difficulty.
Watches a streetcar go by without attempting to board it, instead choosing to walk with canes and endure blisters on his hands, showing persistence but possibly a lack of more efficient action.
Politely greets Mrs. Fuller and warmly accepts introduction to her granddaughter Daisy.
Politely greets Mrs. Fuller and responds confidently to her compliment about his youthful appearance.
Maintains dignity and composure when introduced to Mrs. Fuller's granddaughter and throughout the exchange.
Listens attentively to Queenie's pregnancy announcement, shows visible emotional reaction and sympathy toward others' joys and sorrows.
Asks for clarification when he doesn't understand Queenie's announcement: 'What does she mean "answered her prayers?"'

Sits close to Daisy, listening attentively and expressing delight as Grandma Fuller reads a story.
Follows Daisy quietly down the stairs at night after she comes to check on him, showing attentiveness and trust.
Sits attentively and is engaged while listening to a story being read by Grandma Fuller.
Follows Daisy quietly and carefully at night using his cane, demonstrating physical capability and attentiveness despite his condition.
Follows Daisy quietly into the secret 'fort' and participates in their shared game despite his caution about matches.
Trusts Daisy and shares a personal secret about his youth and mortality in their private moment.
Shows sensitivity and friendliness towards Daisy, maintaining a quiet and sincere interaction with her.
Lights a candle despite knowing he is not supposed to use matches, showing cautious risk-taking and skill.
Responds thoughtfully and calmly to Daisy's secret and questions, showing emotional intelligence and self-awareness.
Doesn't know what to say immediately after hearing Daisy's secret, indicating some social hesitance.
Allows Daisy to touch his cheek patiently; remains quietly forlorn and introspective when confronted about his difference.
Does not react with anger or frustration when Grandma Fuller scolds him and Daisy, accepts the situation calmly.
Asks his mother sincerely 'What's wrong with me?' showing vulnerability and openness.
Withdraws quietly after confrontation without argument or complaint.
Crosses up the back stairs with the aid of his cane, navigating carefully despite his unusual condition.
Sits forlorn and passive after being scolded, questioning 'What's wrong with me?'
Remains mostly passive and silent when confronted by authority figures and during interactions, showing limited assertiveness or confidence.
Turns back to the old man in bed without interaction, just stares out the window lost in thought.
Quietly comes into the kitchen but slips out unseen after seeing Queenie peaceful with her infant.

Lays looking out the window, seemingly lost in thoughts or memories instead of engaging with surroundings or people.
Slips quietly out of the kitchen after seeing Queenie peacefully breastfeeding, showing respect and discretion.
Slips quietly out of the kitchen upon seeing Queenie quietly breastfeeding, not disturbing her moment.

Spends a lot of time by himself feeling alone despite being surrounded by loved ones.
Greets the refined old woman moving in with a simple, polite 'Hello'.

Volunteers enthusiastically to work when others hesitate.

Shows sincere positive attitude by being thrilled and happy to do things even without pay.
Engages in friendly conversation with Captain Mike in the wheelhouse, responds honestly about himself.
Eagerly volunteers to help on the tugboat and willingly does any assigned task, including scraping off bird droppings without complaint.
Admits to not having found out what he was born to do, showing uncertainty about his purpose or direction.
Responds honestly and calmly to Capt. Mike's teasing questions without showing offense or anger.
Admits he has never had a woman, showing sincerity and openness.
Does not react negatively to Capt. Mike's crude teasing, indicating tolerance and good-naturedness.

Calmly points out that Capt. Mike is actually a tugboat captain, effectively highlighting a contradiction in Capt. Mike's identity.

Follows the girl's gentle instruction to clean himself, showing willingness to trust and cooperate.
Looks at change he was given and questions the amount paid for a day's work.
Left standing, not knowing what to do among the women at the whore house.
Follows the girl's suggestion to clean himself using a wash cloth and wash his face, adapting to the situation.

Approaches an unfamiliar situation (intimate encounter) with enthusiasm but lacks experience and skill, excitement gets the best of him.
Shows persistence and eagerness, repeatedly initiating intimacy and maintaining stamina beyond expectations, impressing the girl.

Engages in awkward silence during the car ride, suggesting possible discomfort or uncertainty.
Responds calmly and respectfully when introduced to Thomas Button.
Does not recognize his own father when they meet, indicating limited awareness of his family context.
Admits to inexperience honestly and embraces first-time experiences.
Responds guilelessly and without bitterness about his condition when his father expresses sympathy.
Shares personal information openly, including his adoption and unique condition.

Responds casually and politely to Thomas's request to visit, signaling openness.
Slurs words and behaves drunkenly, wobbling as he tries to enter the house.
Attempts to pay for the drinks with his hard-earned pay, showing pride and a sense of responsibility.
Engages in conversation confidently despite intoxication, asking about Thomas Button's work.

Stops the door from slamming to be considerate and cautious.

Asks what it takes to build a huge ocean liner, showing curiosity and interest in large-scale engineering.
Stands calmly with Daisy on the prow of the tugboat while the horn blares and the ocean liner appears, demonstrating composure in a potentially overwhelming situation.

Reflects on the woman teaching him how to play piano and what it means to miss someone, revealing a sincere and sentimental nature.
Packs his suitcase and says goodbye, indicating readiness to move on but with a sense of closure.

Looks at Elizabeth Abbott with sincere appreciation despite her plain appearance.

Reflects thoughtfully on letting go at the end of life, indicating emotional intelligence and acceptance rather than denial or confusion.
